articles.headline: Silicon Valley Bank Fails After Run on Deposits
articles.snippet: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of the bank’s assets on Friday. The failure raised concerns that other banks could face problems, too.
articles.abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of the bank’s assets on Friday. The failure raised concerns that other banks could face problems, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most prominent lenders in the world of technology start-ups, struggling under the weight of ill-fated decisions and panicked customers, collapsed on Friday, forcing the federal government to step in.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: Third Black-Owned Company Emerges as Suitor for BET
articles.snippet: Black Entertainment Television made the first Black billionaire in the United States. Will a Black executive buy it back?
articles.abstract: Black Entertainment Television made the first Black billionaire in the United States. Will a Black executive buy it back?
articles.lead_paragraph: When the cable giant Viacom bought Black Entertainment Television at the turn of the millennium for $2.34 billion, it made Robert L. Johnson, BET’s founder, the first Black billionaire in the United States.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s Collapse Causes Start-Up Chaos
articles.snippet: Young companies raced to get their money out of the bank, which was central to the start-up industry. Some said they could not make payroll.
articles.abstract: Young companies raced to get their money out of the bank, which was central to the start-up industry. Some said they could not make payroll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ashley Tyrner opened an account with Silicon Valley Bank for her company, FarmboxRx, two years ago. She was setting out to raise venture capital and knew the bank was a go-to for the start-up industry.

articles.headline: In World Cup Run-Up, Qatar Pressed U.N. Agency Not to Investigate Abuses
articles.snippet: Lobbying at the International Labor Organization dovetailed with an influence campaign that set off a corruption scandal at the European Parliament.
articles.abstract: Lobbying at the International Labor Organization dovetailed with an influence campaign that set off a corruption scandal at the European Parliament.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a series of raids and arrests this winter, the Belgian authorities unearthed what they said was a dirty deal at the heart of the European Parliament. Politicians are charged with pocketing money to praise the tiny Gulf nation of Qatar and downplay its labor rights abuses in the run-up to the World Cup.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sarah Hurtes

articles.headline: Chinese-Brokered Deal Upends Mideast Diplomacy and Challenges U.S.
articles.snippet: The agreement negotiated in Beijing to restore relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled at least a temporary reordering of the usual alliances and rivalries, with Washington left on the sidelines.
articles.abstract: The agreement negotiated in Beijing to restore relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled at least a temporary reordering of the usual alliances and rivalries, with Washington left on the sidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Finally, there is a peace deal of sorts in the Middle East. Not between Israel and the Arabs, but between Saudi Arabia and Iran, which have been at each other’s throats for decades. And brokered not by the United States but by China.

articles.headline: Inside Ron DeSantis’s Politicized Removal of an Elected Prosecutor
articles.snippet: The Florida governor accused the Democratic prosecutor of undermining public safety. But a close examination of the episode reveals just how fueled it was by Mr. DeSantis’s political aims.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor accused the Democratic prosecutor of undermining public safety. But a close examination of the episode reveals just how fueled it was by Mr. DeSantis’s political aims.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida announced last summer that he had taken the extraordinary step of removing a local prosecutor from his job, he cast his decision as a bold move to protect Floridians.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: Can the United Farm Workers Rise Again?
articles.snippet: Decades after Cesar Chavez made the union a power in California fields, it has lost much of its clout. Membership dropped precipitously, from 60,000 to 5,500. It hopes a new law will turn the tide.
articles.abstract: Decades after Cesar Chavez made the union a power in California fields, it has lost much of its clout. Membership dropped precipitously, from 60,000 to 5,500. It hopes a new law will turn the tide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Veronica Mota marched under the sweltering sun, hoisting a cloth banner of Our Lady of Guadalupe above her head for miles.
articles.byline: By Kurtis Lee and Liliana Michelena

articles.headline: Fox’s P.R. Woes May Not Directly Translate to Legal Ones
articles.snippet: Some of the unflattering private messages among the network’s hosts and executives may never become evidence when Dominion Voting Systems’ defamation case against Fox News goes to trial.
articles.abstract: Some of the unflattering private messages among the network’s hosts and executives may never become evidence when Dominion Voting Systems’ defamation case against Fox News goes to trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past three weeks, a drip, drip, drip of disclosures have exposed widespread alarm and disbelief inside Fox News in the days after the 2020 presidential election, as the network became a platform for some of the most insidious lies about widespread voter fraud. These revelations are the most damning to rattle the Murdoch media empire since the phone hacking scandal in Britain more than a decade ago.

articles.headline: Making Deepfakes Gets Cheaper and Easier Thanks to A.I.
articles.snippet: Meme-makers and misinformation peddlers are embracing artificial intelligence tools to create convincing fake videos on the cheap.
articles.abstract: Meme-makers and misinformation peddlers are embracing artificial intelligence tools to create convincing fake videos on the cheap.
articles.lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t be completely out of character for Joe Rogan, the comedian turned podcaster, to endorse a “libido-boosting” coffee brand for men.

articles.headline: Regulators Close Another Bank and Move to Protect Deposits
articles.snippet: The Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation unveiled a plan to contain fallout from Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse, and said taxpayers would not bear the costs.
articles.abstract: The Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation unveiled a plan to contain fallout from Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse, and said taxpayers would not bear the costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators announced on Sunday that another bank had been closed and that the government would ensure that all depositors of Silicon Valley Bank — which failed Friday — would be paid back in full as Washington rushed to keep fallout from the collapse of the large institution from sweeping through the financial system.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: War in Ukraine Puts Centuries of Swiss Neutrality to the Test
articles.snippet: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
articles.abstract: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Eastern Europe, Ukrainians are in the trenches. Farther west, European capitals are grappling with a new order in which war is no longer theoretical. Yet, tucked away in the heart of the continent, the Swiss are fretting over loftier ideals.

articles.headline: Spiraling Dispute With Star Host Puts BBC’s Reputation on the Line
articles.snippet: The British public broadcaster’s suspension of one of its highest-profile sports anchors has grown into a wider controversy that poses risks to its reputation for neutrality and independence.
articles.abstract: The British public broadcaster’s suspension of one of its highest-profile sports anchors has grown into a wider controversy that poses risks to its reputation for neutrality and independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an English soccer star, Gary Lineker was renowned for never having been penalized with a yellow or red card in his 16-year career. As a politically opinionated sports broadcaster for the BBC, Mr. Lineker has tangled regularly with the officials, and his suspension over a Twitter post on immigration this week escalated into a crisis that now engulfs the British Broadcasting Corporation.

articles.headline: In Budget Talks, Biden Rejects Hard Choices of the Past
articles.snippet: The president has met Republican demands for debt reduction with a plan to trim deficits by taxing companies and the rich.
articles.abstract: The president has met Republican demands for debt reduction with a plan to trim deficits by taxing companies and the rich.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after losing control of the House in 2010, President Barack Obama and his vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., released a budget proposal that bowed to Republican warnings about the need to rein in spending by promising a freeze in popular programs like education.

articles.headline: An A.I. Start-Up Boomed, but Now It Faces a Slowing Economy and New Rules
articles.snippet: Using A.I. tools in hiring is one of the most promising and contentious uses of the technology. The experience of a company called Eightfold AI shows the challenges.
articles.abstract: Using A.I. tools in hiring is one of the most promising and contentious uses of the technology. The experience of a company called Eightfold AI shows the challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2016, two computer scientists, both Google alumni, bet that artificial intelligence could help make smarter hiring and promotion decisions.

articles.headline: Opioid Settlement Hinders Patients’ Access to a Wide Array of Drugs
articles.snippet: An agreement between attorneys general and major drug distributors increased scrutiny on medications for A.D.H.D., addiction, anxiety and pain.
articles.abstract: An agreement between attorneys general and major drug distributors increased scrutiny on medications for A.D.H.D., addiction, anxiety and pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a sweeping opioid settlement imposed new requirements on the companies that provide medications to pharmacies, patients across the United States are having difficulty obtaining drugs to treat many conditions, including anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and addiction.
articles.byline: By Christina Jewett and Ellen Gabler

articles.headline: UPenn Accuses a Law Professor of Racist Statements. Should She Be Fired?
articles.snippet: Amy Wax and free speech groups say the university is trampling on her academic freedom. Students ask whether her speech deserves to be protected.
articles.abstract: Amy Wax and free speech groups say the university is trampling on her academic freedom. Students ask whether her speech deserves to be protected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amy Wax, a law professor, has said publicly that “on average, Blacks have lower cognitive ability than whites,” that the country is “better off with fewer Asians” as long as they tend to vote for Democrats, and that non-Western people feel a “tremendous amount of resentment and shame.”

articles.headline: Colleges Have Been a Small-Town Lifeline. What Happens as They Shrink?
articles.snippet: Declining student enrollment is hitting the rural areas that rely on universities. They’re trying to adapt to survive.
articles.abstract: Declining student enrollment is hitting the rural areas that rely on universities. They’re trying to adapt to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: China’s New Premier Needs to Revive Growth. How Far Will Loyalty Get Him?
articles.snippet: Li Qiang’s business-friendly reputation could bolster confidence in China’s economy. But he is stepping into a role with diminished power under Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: Li Qiang’s business-friendly reputation could bolster confidence in China’s economy. But he is stepping into a role with diminished power under Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Li Qiang was appointed China’s No. 2 leader this past week, he oversaw Shanghai, a city that, for a time early last year, was celebrated for trying to contain Covid with relative restraint. City officials wanted to avoid the economic devastation of a full-scale lockdown and instead opted for limited restrictions that applied to, in one instance, a single milk tea shop.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Chang Che

articles.headline: Federal Reserve’s Path Is Murkier After Bank Blowup
articles.snippet: The Fed has been rapidly raising interest rates to fight inflation. But making big moves could be trickier amid instability.
articles.abstract: The Fed has been rapidly raising interest rates to fight inflation. But making big moves could be trickier amid instability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s hotly anticipated March 22 interest rate decision is just a week and a half away, and the drama that swept the banking and financial sector over the weekend is drastically shaking up expectations for what the central bank will deliver.
